item.title: India Ink: India Election Digest: April 28
item.description: A roundup of election-related news for Monday.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ
item.media:description: Sonia Gandhi, president of the Congress party, at a rally on Thursday in Kheralu, in the western Indian state of Gujarat.

item.title: North Korean Peace Group Insults South Korean Leader
item.description: The North’s Committee for the Peaceful Reunification of Korea described Park Geun-hye in misogynic terms and called President Obama her “pimp.”
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Communist Mouthpiece Says it Complained to Twitter About Parody
item.description: People’s Daily, the flagship paper of China’s Communist Party, continued its assault on a Twitter account that parodies the country’s rulers, saying it violates Twitter’s rules.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Salon of the Exiled
item.description: Critics of the Russian government are being framed on bogus charges and forced to flee the country.
item.dc:creator: By MASHA GESSEN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The New Censors of Hanoi
item.description: Market-driven concerns may be hampering artists in Vietnam more than censorship did under classically Communist governments.
item.dc:creator: By NGUYEN QUI DUC

item.title: In Venezuela, Protesters Point to Their Scars
item.description: President Nicolás Maduro, fearing efforts to overthrow him, said he held the opposition responsible for the violence that, by some accounts, had claimed more than 40 lives.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Clipso Martínez, recovering from surgery performed on his leg, said he was shot at point-blank range by a soldier during a protest.

item.title: U.S. Weighs Harder Line on Russia Than European Allies
item.description: The White House has become entangled in a debate over how much emphasis to put on unity with European allies reluctant to take stronger economic actions against Moscow, while pro-Russian forces in Ukraine continue to defy demands.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and C. J. CHIVERS

item.title: South Korean Leader Accepts Resignation of Premier Over Ferry Disaster
item.description: President Park Geun-hye accepted the resignation of Prime Minister Chung Hong-won but asked him to stay in his post until the government completed its rescue operations, an official said.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Prime Minister Chung Hong-won of South Korea announced his resignation at a news conference in Seoul on Sunday.

item.title: Muslims Leave Central African Republic Capital Under Escort
item.description: Peacekeeping troops escorted about 1,300 Muslims out of Bangui on Sunday, setting off looting and removing one of the last pockets of Muslims from the capital of a nation torn apart by religious violence.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The War on Truth in Ukraine
item.description: In the absence of hard facts, disinformation and manipulation win.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH A. DARDEN

item.title: U.S. and Philippines Agree to a 10-Year Pact on the Use of Military Bases
item.description: The accord will give American warships, planes and troops greater access to bases in the Philippines, returning the United States to a visible presence there for the first time since 1992.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: Paris Journal: On Bridges in Paris, Clanking With Love
item.description: Romantics from around the world affirm their love by affixing padlocks to certain bridges in Paris. But some see not a touching symbol of commitment, but an eyesore.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: A just-married couple poses for photos on Pont des Arts, one of the bridges where lovers hitch padlocks symbolic of undying love.

item.title: Putin Rival Takes Message to East Ukraine
item.description: Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the Russian tycoon, flew to Donetsk to see whether the standoffs were as hard and dangerous as they seem from a distance.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the former oil tycoon, at a meeting on Sunday with civic society groups in Donetsk, where he urged the importance of standing up for one’s beliefs.

item.title: A European Energy Executive’s Delicate Dance Over Ukraine
item.description: The Italian energy giant ENI is the biggest distributor of Russian gas in Europe, but its chief is risking Moscow’s wrath by trying to help Kiev.
item.dc:creator: By STANLEY REED and JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: ENI, an Italian energy firm, is a partner with the Russian gas supplier Gazprom on a pipeline that would bypass Ukraine.

item.title: Qaddafi Son Appears on Screen at His Trial
item.description: Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi is accused of aiding his father Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in the brutal suppression of Libya’s uprising three years ago.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By SULIMAN ALI ZWAY and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Forced to Flee Radiation, Fearful Japanese Villagers Are Reluctant to Return
item.description: Three years after the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear accident, the government has reopened the evacuated community of Miyakoji. But many do not want to come back.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.media:description: “The government and the media say the radiation has been cleaned up, but it’s all lies,” said Miyakoji villager Kim Eunja, with her husband, Satoshi Mizuochi.

item.title: National Pride Swells the Crowds for a Polish Saint
item.description: St. Peter’s Square was awash with Polish flags as pilgrims celebrated the canonization ceremony of John Paul II, the first Polish pope.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Afghan Voters Signaling a Turn
item.description: In preliminary results released Saturday, Abdullah Abdullah, a longtime opponent of President Hamid Karzai’s and an ardent supporter of the United States, won 45 percent of the votes in the presidential election, but not enough to avoid a runoff.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: Abdullah Abdullah, shown at his residence in Kabul on Thursday, is one of two candidates expected to compete in a runoff election.

item.title: Pro-Russian Forces in Ukraine Free One of 8 Detainees
item.description: The self-appointed mayor of Slovyansk in eastern Ukraine presented the men at a news conference Sunday, calling them “prisoners of the situation,” before releasing one member for health reasons.
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS and NOAH SNEIDER
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of a group of European military observers who were detained on Friday were escorted by antigovernment militants on Sunday to a news conference in Slovyansk, Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: Syria Misses New Deadline as It Works to Purge Arms
item.description: Although Syria has made “significant progress,” it missed a second deadline, April 27, for the destruction of its arsenal of chemical weapons, international monitors said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Mahmoud Abbas Shifts on Holocaust
item.description: The president of the Palestinian Authority issued a formal statement calling the Holocaust “the most heinous crime to have occurred against humanity in the modern era.”
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: A planned statement by President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority grew out of a meeting with a rabbi.

item.title: On Historic Day, John XXIII and John Paul II Become Saints
item.description: Before large, joyous crowds in Rome, Pope Francis performed a joint canonization on Sunday for his papal predecessors, whom he portrayed as “men of courage” with a shared place in history.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY

item.title: Listening Post: In Malaysia, Obama Works to Mend Troubled Ties
item.description: President Obama’s visit to Malaysia underscored the change in the country’s attitude toward the United States, from deep suspicion to a desire for cooperation.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: President Obama, with Prime Minister Najib Razak of Malaysia, answered questions from youth leaders at the Malaysia Global Innovation and Creativity Center in Kuala Lumpur on Sunday.

item.title: News Analysis: For Russia, Negatives Seem to Outweigh Positives of an Invasion
item.description: The reasons for Vladimir V. Putin to refrain from further military adventurism make a long, tangled list.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Government troops outside Slovyansk on Saturday. The army is weak, but Ukraine has a history of partisans’ attacking invaders.

item.title: Sanctions Revive Search for Secret Putin Fortune
item.description: President Obama’s response to the Ukraine crisis, while derided by critics as slow and weak, has reinvigorated a 15-year global hunt for the Russian leader’s hidden wealth.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Mikhail Klimentiev/Ria Novosti/Kremlin
item.media:description: The Treasury Department says President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has investments in Gunvor, a commodities trading firm.
